options.D: The right atrium and the left ventricle mainly form the inferior border of the heart.

questions.question: You are shown a CT scan of the chest. The scan is taken in the arterial phase. Based on the anatomy and contrast enhancement, identify the structure marked as ‘A’ by the arrow.
questions.explanation: which is the left atrium. On an axial CT scan of the heart in the arterial phase: Left atrium (LA): Posteriorly and superiorly to the left ventricle. Left ventricle (LV): The thick-walled, highly muscular, most prominent chamber is seen in the left inferior portion of the axial slice. Pulmonary trunk: Lies anterior to the left atrium and superior to the left ventricle. Right ventricle (RV): Anteriormost chamber present retrosternally, appears on the right side of the heart on an axial CT scan and has thinner walls than the left ventricle. Left atrium: Seen posteriorly.

questions.question: A 25-year-old male presents with mild exertional dyspnea. Clinical examination reveals a fixed split S2 and a systolic ejection murmur at the left upper sternal border. A chest X-ray shows the following features. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Anomalous Pulmonary Venous Connection (PAPVC) A congenital anomaly where one or more but not all pulmonary veins drain into the right atrium or systemic venous circulation instead of the left atrium. This leads to a left-to-right shunt, causing volume overload on the right side of the heart and pulmonary circulation. Most common variant - the left upper pulmonary vein draining into the right atrium. Other variants drain into SVC, coronary sinus, IVC, or azygos veins. The chest X-ray typically shows mild cardiomegaly, right atrial and ventricular enlargement, and increased pulmonary vasculature , especially in the right lung field. Scimitar syndrome - When a part or whole of the right lung is drained by anomalous pulmonary veins that connect to IVC, leading to hypoplastic right lung. Chest X-ray shows anomalous vein parallel to right heart border mimicking Turkish sword (Scimitar). Although VSD (Option B) also causes a left-to-right shunt, the characteristic murmur is a holosystolic murmur best heard at the left lower sternal border, and chest X-ray findings typically show biventricular enlargement. Mitral Stenosis (Option C) usually presents with left atrial enlargement on X-ray and features like pulmonary venous congestion. questions.question: A 31-year-old man presents with dyspnea, orthopnea and fatigue. The radiological images are attached below. Based on the given information, which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: calcification. This finding is characteristic of constrictive pericarditis. Calcific constrictive pericarditis is a chronic condition where the pericardium becomes thickened, fibrotic, and often calcified, leading to impaired diastolic filling of the heart. The images demonstrate a thickened and calcified pericardium , which is a hallmark of this condition. Calcific Constrictive Pericarditis Etiology Often idiopathic, can be secondary to infection, radiation, or autoimmune diseases Pathophysiology Thickened, fibrotic, and calcified pericardium restricting cardiac filling Clinical Presentation Dyspnea, fatigue, chest pain, signs of right heart failure CT Findings (IOC) • Thickened pericardium (>4 mm), often calcified • Pericardial effusion may be present • Dilation of inferior vena cava and hepatic veins Other Imaging Cardiac MRI- To measure pericardial thickness Acute Pericarditis (Option A) Acute

questions.question: A 3-day-old newborn is brought to the emergency department with marked central cyanosis. On examination, his heart rate is 160 bpm, respiratory rate is 65 breaths/min, and oxygen saturation is 80% on room air. A chest radiograph is performed, showing cardiomegaly with a characteristic "egg on a string" appearance. If an echocardiogram is conducted, which of the following echocardiographic findings would be most consistent with the suspected condition?

options.A: Ventricular septal defect with overriding aorta
options.B: Single great artery arising from the heart
options.C: Parallel great vessels with the aorta anterior and slightly to the right of the pulmonary artery
options.D: Abnormal pulmonary venous connections to the right atrium

questions.explanation: pulmonary artery artery Explanation: The clinical presentation and imaging findings are highly suggestive of Transposition of the Great Arteries (TGA), specifically D-loop TGA . In TGA, the great vessels (aorta and pulmonary artery) run parallel to each other, with the aorta positioned anterior and slightly to the right of the pulmonary artery. This arrangement is due to the ventriculoarterial discordance characteristic of TGA. Key points supporting the diagnosis of D-Loop TGA in this case: Early presentation with marked central cyanosis without respiratory distress History of maternal diabetes (associated risk factor) Chest X-ray showing cardiomegaly with an "egg on a string" appearance Echocardiographic finding of parallel great vessels with abnormal positioning D-Loop TGA ( dextro-transposition of the great arteries) L-Loop TGA (Congenitally Corrected) Pathology The aorta originates from the right ventricle and the pulmonary trunk from the left ventricle, creating two parallel circulatory circuits. This condition is life-threatening unless a shunt, like a patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) or septal defect, is present to allow blood mixing. Congenitally corrected TGA (ccTGA) is characterized by both atrioventricular and ventriculoarterial discordance, a condition referred to as "double discordance." X-ray Cardiomegaly "Egg on a string" appearance Narrow mediastinum Increased pulmonary vascular markings Mesocardia or levocardia Straight left heart border Abnormally straight vascular pedicle Possible bulge along upper left cardiac border Ventricular septal defect with overriding aorta is characteristic of Tetralogy of Fallot, not TGA (Option A) . A single great artery arising from the heart is the hallmark of Truncus Arteriosus, not TGA (Option B) . Abnormal pulmonary venous connections to the right atrium are seen in Total Anomalous Pulmonary Venous Return, not TGA (Option D) .

questions.question: A 45-year-old woman presents with gradually worsening dyspnea and reduced exercise tolerance over the past month. The chest X-ray is given below. Regarding this patient's condition, which of the following statements is INCORRECT?

options.A: "Oreo cookie" sign will be seen on lateral view on Chest X Ray
options.B: The patient typically shows abrupt enlargement of cardiothoracic ratio
options.C: Seldinger technique is employed for management of this condition
options.D: An Echocardiogram is a better modality than CT to confirm the diagnosis

questions.explanation: clinical presentation and radiological image indicate towards pericardial effusion. In pericardial effusion, especially when symptoms develop gradually over a month as in this case, the enlargement of the cardiothoracic ratio is typically gradual , not abrupt. The Seldinger technique is used in pericardiocentesis for managing significant pericardial effusions. (Option C) Pericardial effusion- Radiological findings Imaging Modality Radiological Findings Notes Plain Radiograph • Globular enlargement of cardiac shadow • "Water bottle" configuration • Widening of the subcarinal angle • "Oreo cookie" sign on lateral view (Option A) • Serially enlarging cardiothoracic ratio • Usually visible when >200 mL of fluid present • May show signs of cardiogenic pulmonary edema in severe cases Echocardiography • Anechoic separation of pericardial layers • Fluid first

questions.question: A 68-year-old female patient presents to the emergency department with complaints of increasing shortness of breath over the past few weeks and occasional palpitations. She has a history of hypertension and was diagnosed with mitral stenosis five years ago. A chest X-ray is performed, and the radiologist notes specific findings. Based on the chest X-ray findings, which of the following features is most indicative of the condition observed?

options.A: Elevation of the left main bronchus
options.D: Cardiomegaly with a normal heart border

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Elevation of the left main bronchus Explanation: In this scenario, the chest X-ray findings indicate left atrial enlargement, and the elevation of the left main bronchus serves as a characteristic feature where the enlarged left atrium can push the left main bronchus upward which correlates with the patient's history of mitral stenosis. Left Atrial Enlargement . Radiographic Features Double Density : Extra shadow along the right heart border due to the enlarged left atrium. Right Heart Border : Formation of a “double” right heart border. Bronchial Changes : Elevation of the left main bronchus. Horizontal orientation of the distal left bronchus.

questions.question: In mitral stenosis, which Mogul sign is seen?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Third Explanation: Third Mogul Sign is typically formed by a prominent left atrial appendage, which is often observed in patients with rheumatic mitral stenosis due to left atrial enlargement. Normal Moguls on the Left Cardiac Border: Aortic Knuckle (first bump) Pulmonary Artery (second bump) Left Atrial Appendage (third bump, below the left main bronchus) Cardiac Apex (fourth bump) Third Mogul sign: Typically formed by a prominent left atrial appendage, often seen in patients with rheumatic mitral stenosis due to left atrial enlargement.

questions.question: A 70-year-old male patient presents to the emergency department with acute respiratory distress following a severe allergic reaction. He has a history of asthma and reports recent exposure to a known allergen. Chest X-ray of the patient is given below. Which of the following findings on the chest X-ray is NOT characteristic of the patient’s condition?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Widened Mediastinum Explanation: The patient is experiencing acute respiratory distress likely due to non-cardiogenic pulmonary edema (NCPE) as a result of a severe allergic reaction. Conditions like Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS) can occur in response to allergens, leading to increased permeability of the alveolar-capillary barrier and resulting in pulmonary edema. Widened Mediastinum is NOT characteristic of pulmonary edema. A widened mediastinum is usually indicative of conditions such as aortic dissection, large mediastinal tumors, or significant vascular issues, rather than pulmonary edema. Non-Cardiogenic Pulmonary Edema: Caused by increased permeability of the alveolar-capillary barrier (not due to heart failure). Common Cause: Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS). Features on Chest X-ray: Interstitial Edema Signs: Kerley B Lines: Short horizontal lines at lung periphery due to fluid in the interlobular septa. (Option D ruled out) Kerley A Lines: Longer lines directed towards the hilum (more difficult to detect).

questions.question: A 60-year-old male with hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and a smoking history presents for a routine evaluation. He has no symptoms but is concerned about cardiovascular health due to a family history of heart disease. Which score is used to assess coronary artery disease risk?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Agatston Score Explanation: The Agatston Score is used to assess coronary artery disease (CAD) risk by quantifying the amount of coronary artery calcification seen on a CT scan. Higher scores indicate a higher burden of coronary atherosclerosis and increased cardiovascular risk. Coronary Atherosclerosis Coronary atherosclerosis is the buildup of plaques in the coronary arteries, leading to reduced blood flow and increasing the risk of cardiovascular events. Agatston Score Purpose: The Agatston score quantifies coronary artery calcium (CAC) detected via computed tomography (CT). It helps assess the risk of coronary artery disease (CAD). Calculation: The score is derived from the density and area of calcified plaques in the coronary arteries. Higher scores indicate a greater burden of coronary calcification and a higher risk of coronary events. Coronary calcium lesion = CT density of 130 Hounsfield units with area >1mm2. Interpretation: 0: No identifiable calcium, low risk of coronary events. 1-99: Mild coronary calcium, moderate risk. 100-399: Moderate to high risk. ≥ 400: High risk, indicating significant atherosclerotic burden. CHA2DS2-VASc Score (Option A) is used to assess the risk of stroke in patients with atrial fibrillation, not CAD risk. Reynolds Risk Score (Option C) is a tool used to predict cardiovascular risk, but it incorporates more factors such as high-sensitivity C-reactive protein (hs-CRP) and is not specifically for coronary artery calcification. Carotid Intima-Media Thickness (CIMT) (Option D) is not specific to coronary artery disease risk as it measures the thickness of the carotid artery walls, not coronary artery calcification or plaque burden.

questions.question: A 10-year-old boy presents with brachio-femoral pulse delay and a history of recurrent chest pain. A chest X-ray is performed, revealing a contour abnormality of the aorta and rib notching. Which of the following radiographic features is most likely observed in this patient?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Figure of 3 sign Explanation: The presence of the Figure of 3 sign and rib notching on X-ray, along with symptoms of hypertension and chest pain, indicates coarctation of the aorta . These findings suggest narrowed aorta leading to collateral circulation and rib erosion, confirming the diagnosis. Figure of 3 sign: This sign indicates a contour abnormality of the aorta commonly associated with coarctation of the aorta. It is characterized by a distinctive "3" shape formed by the aorta and adjacent structures on the X-ray. Radiographic Features of Coarctation of the Aorta (CoA) Plain Radiograph Findings Figure of 3 Sign Contour abnormality of the aorta, indicative of coarctation. Inferior Rib Notching (Roesler Sign) Erosion of the inferior margins of ribs (usually 4th–8th) by dilated intercostal collateral vessels. Seen in long-standing cases (70% of older children/adults). Rare in infancy or children <5 years. Collateral Pathways Increased subclavian artery flow promotes collateral formation via: Internal thoracic arteries Anterior and posterior intercostal arteries Rib Notching Patterns Bilateral Rib Notching : Coarctation distal to both subclavian arteries. Unilateral Right Rib

questions.question: A 72-year-old male with a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia presents to the emergency department with sudden, severe abdominal pain radiating to the back. A CT angiogram is given below. Which of the following radiological signs on the CT angiogram indicates an impending rupture of the patient's condition?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Draped aorta sign Explanation: The patient's symptoms and CT angiogram findings indicate an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA), defined as a dilation of the abdominal aorta greater than 3 cm. The sudden severe abdominal pain radiating to the back, combined with the draped aorta sign, suggests an impending rupture, necessitating urgent intervention due to the high mortality rate associated with ruptured AAAs. Draped aorta sign is a crucial indicator of an impending rupture or contained leak of the AAA,. Radiographic Features Plain Radiograph : May show curvilinear calcification in the paravertebral region; not adequate for detailed detection or follow-up.. CT Angiography (CTA) : Gold standard for AAA evaluation; excellent for preoperative planning and accurate measurement of size and shape.. Signs of Rupture : Retroperitoneal Hematoma : Blood collection in the retroperitoneal space. (Option A ruled out) Para-aortic Fat Stranding : Indicates inflammation around the aorta. (Option D ruled out) Contrast Extravasation : Leakage of contrast from the aorta. (Option B ruled out) Signs of Impending Rupture : Draped Aorta Sign : Suggests contained rupture.
